title: How do parents instill a love of mathematics into their children? - Quora

response.answer_text: Parents can only do so much. Years ago, we had an old encyclopedia. It was way out of date, and my young sons wanted a new one. My husband and I could no way afford an actual brand new set of encyclopedias, so we watched on Craig’s List for someone selling a set that wasn’t too old. Lucky us, we found one that was only a couple years old. A mother had purchased the set for her son, but he wouldn’t use it. When we came to her house to look at the encyclopedia, we brought our kids. They ran to it, and were super jazzed that the set looked new, and had been published only a couple years before. I was glad to buy the set, it had clearly not been used. The gold leaf on the page edges made that satisfying crack sound, every volume I picked up. The mother asked me how I got my kids to be so happy about an encyclopedia set. I looked her right in the eye, and said, “To learn to get excited about an encyclopedia, they have to see the parents using it and being excited about it, first.” That kid wasn’t the only one not using that pristine encyclopedia.  When my sons were little, both were interested in math. We had all kinds of math manipulatives available for them to play with, picture books with math themes, math flashcards, calculators, math puzzles…generally, math was never held separate from the idea of fun. One of my sons was clearly good at math from a stunningly young age. The other son was so into math he preferred math flash cards over a story or song at bedtime. I did not do anything different with those boys. But one had math ability, and one had a deep love of math.  Parents can make learning fun, by having fun learning. Parents cannot make their children engage in something the parents themselves will obviously not engage in. Opportunity to engage in learning (math or anything else) and roll models of enjoying learning hard things is a necessary but insufficient part of the process to help a child learn to love math or anything else. Kids who do come to love math, got there because they had the opportunity when they wanted and needed it, but also felt a natural affinity for it. Many people in my family loved sports when I was growing up. And almost every member of my family came to love sports—playing sports, watching sports live, watching sports on TV, following sports in the news—but not me. I can appreciate the work that goes into sports, I can appreciate the grace and drama, the dedication, the camaraderie, I understand the rules of most common sports. But I don’t love sports. I enjoyed watching my husband and my sons play when they did, but only because it was them. I literally don’t remember any particular game they won or lost. I remember the time one of my sons made a double play after being hit in the mouth with a baseball, and rushing my bloody son to the dental surgeon to fix the damage. No, I don’t love sports. And nothing anyone ever did or said was going to change that. Parents cannot “instill” love. They can only provide the option to love. The rest is up to the kids.

As a parent, you need to realize that teaching kid in the right way and at the right time can make them perfect in every subject. Children usually hate math, so you need to fill love for math in your child's heart by: By playing games- parents should play with them by picture books having math themes, math puzzles, math flashcards, etc. When kids start playing with it, they will find it exciting and fun to learn math.By daily practice, - Parents should involve math practice in their kid's daily routine. The more they practice, the more they get interested. Love for math can only create by removing the fear of math from their hearts.Teach positive points of math- Kids find math boring and a not exciting subject, so only parents can make it enjoyable by telling them the positive aspects of math. By teaching them the importance of math in their lives, you can do this by linking certain things with math concepts like addition, subtraction, division, and multiplication.For more information, check out 98thPercentile website here.
